conclusion: To determine the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground.
The basketball experiences two forces during its motion: gravitational force and air resistance.
During free fall, net force is mg(1 - λ). During upward motion, net force is mg(λ - 1).
The basketball is dropped from a height H and rebounds to a height h.
Energy lost during the collision is due to inelastic collision and work done against air resistance.
Work done by air resistance during fall is λmgH.
Kinetic energy just before collision is mgH(1 - λ).
Let the ratio of post-collision velocity to pre-collision velocity be e.
Kinetic energy immediately after collision is e²mgH(1 - λ).
Work done by air resistance during upward motion is λmgh.
At maximum height h, potential energy is mgh.
Energy balance during upward motion: e²mgH(1 - λ) - λmgh = mgh.
Divide through by mg: e²H(1 - λ) - λh = h.
Rearrange to isolate e²: e²H(1 - λ) = h(1 + λ).
Solve for e²: e² = h(1 + λ) / H(1 - λ).
Take the square root to find e: e = √(h(1 + λ) / H(1 - λ)).
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is e = √(h(1 + λ) / H(1 - λ)).
